# ğŸ bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- âœï¸edit: -->
Not sure, whatever handles populating HTML templates.

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- âœï¸-->
No idea, sorry.


### Description

<!-- âœï¸-->
A great example is x-frame-bypass, and this confused user in particular:

https://github.com/niutech/x-frame-bypass/issues/22

x-frame-bypass is a custom element that inherits from iframe and does some... interesting things. Regardless, if you drop it into angular and attempt to use it in an HTML template, it's clear a normal iframe gets created despite the output HTML being correct. If you manually use element.innerHTML to inject the custom element it works properly.

## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ztlius

Top frame is added with HTML templates, bottom with innerHtml injection. Both tags should function identically.

## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error
Placing breakpoints in the constructor of the x-frame-bypass class will confirm it is only instantiated for the bottom frame. It looks like the top frame is being instantiated as a normal iframe.

## ğŸŒ  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
Angular CLI: 11.1.4
Node: 14.16.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.1.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

typescript                      4.1.5

Also, reproduces in stackblitz which I assume is the latest and greatest?

**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: "data-id" gets converted to "id" when used with {{ }}
Issues.Body:
### Description When adding a `data-id` to an element, which just uses static text, it gets output as `data-id` attribute. However when adding a dynamic variable to the data-id attribute (e.g.: `data-id="test-{{name}}"`) and id property gets rendered to the html element. ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2032760/112471832-ad651780-8d6c-11eb-92b2-a673423d8fb2.png) ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction ```
This div has a data-id

This div has an id but should have a data-id too.
``` https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-kib5sx?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error data-id with a dynamic attribute gets rendered as data-id too **Anything else relevant?** A workaround is to use `[attr.data-id]="'test-'+name"`. ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2032760/112472110-092fa080-8d6d-11eb-9f0b-3f3ee6beac67.png) This however makes the code longer and harder to read. Note 2: these `data-id`s are used by our TA team and therefore we have a lot of them. AFAIK using these attr syntax is generates a bigger code and to be consitent with one syntax we use `[attr.data-id]` if when it is not needed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ""data-id" gets converted to "id" when used with {{ }}" (#41345)

Issues.Title: Angular 10.2.4 xi18n with --ivy: equiv-text contains wrong value when using CRLF line endings
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report ### Affected Package Probably @angular/cli @angular/compiler @angular/localize ### Is this a regression? Similar bugs were already fixed multiple times #38694 #38711 #39654 ### Description From what I've gathered from the other bugs when you have Windows line endings CRLF the source maps only generate one character for it, which causes the source maps to become misaligned. This causes the `equiv-text` to contain the wrong value: ```

Test asdf

``` Becomes **equiv-text="y-asdf"**: ``` Test asdf src/app/app.component.html 13 ``` In the latest Angular 11 version this is fixed, but since Angular 10 is LTS I really hope you will fix this for the older version as well. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/stefan-schweiger/angular-10-xi18n-crlf-bug You need to make sure to check out the project with CRLF line endings (or format the files yourself). Then just run `ng xi18n --output-path src/locale --ivy` ## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:** 10.2.4 (10.2.3 for cli)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular 10.2.4 xi18n with --ivy: equiv-text contains wrong value when using CRLF line endings" (#41346)

Issues.Title: Consider supporting `styles` and `styleUrls` defined with `as const` in different buildable units
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ feature request

### Relevant Package

@angular/compiler

### Description
Ivy compiler requires all `@Component` metadata to be resolved statically. So generally it's not possible to declare an array of styles of style URLs in a different buildable units and use them in the current one, since the actual values would not be available in D.TS files (only corresponding type declarations). However declaring such arrays with `as const` modifier pulls the value into D.TS files and Ivy compiler can technically leverage this information:

In TS:
```
const styles = ['margin: 0px', 'padding: 0px'] as const;
const styleUrls = ['./style-a.css', './style-b.css'] as const;
```

Corresponding D.TS:
```
declare const styles: readonly ["margin: 0px", "padding: 0px"];
declare const styleUrls: readonly ["./style-a.css", "./style-b.css"];
```

(same example in [TypeScript playground](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play?ssl=3&ssc=63&pln=2&pc=1#code/MYewdgzgLgBFCmBbADgGwIYJgXhgcnQCNg8BuAKFElmgE9V4IcYBtPRdAJwHMBLMAFwwADMgAeeADT5k6ACZz+3IaIkBdGOiZVoFHTSj14AVU6omuNgDoA9HQYBadFeAQIU-LfvwHhF27wNLRh9CiA))

Currently the compiler's static evaluation can understand string literal types, but not tuple types.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider supporting `styles` and `styleUrls` defined with `as const` in different buildable units" (#41338)

Issues.Title: ci: fix `elements` test on older browsers
Issues.Body:
Some `elements` tests rely on `window.customElements` being available. On browsers where this was not present, the tests were skipped.

This commit includes the `@webcomponents/custom-elements` polyfill in order to be able to run all `elements` tests on older browsers, which do not natively support Custom Elements.

This, also, fixes the [saucelabs_ivy][1] and [saucelabs_view_engine][2] CI jobs (part of the `monitoring` workflow), which have been failing recently on IE 11 (probably due to the update to TS 4.2.3).

[1]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/944291
[2]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/944289
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: fix `elements` test on older browsers" (#41324)

# ğŸ“š Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

In "Reusable Animations" one should mention the most simple way of reusing identical animation in multiple components:
Exctract the trigger/transition as `const` and use this in all components. This is probably resolving many developers needs with less overhead than the documented `useAnimation` way.

See e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/a/39463660/2544163

Issues.Title: Select dropdowns with ngValue binding perform far worse than expected
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/forms

### Is this a regression?

Regression from AngularJS.

### Description

I noticed that there was a noticeable delay when populating a select dropdown with several hundred+ items using an ngValue binding, which does not occur with other frameworks (I also tested AngularJS and Svelte). Digging into the Angular code it turns out that the `_compareWith` function in select_control_value_accessor.ts is being called an absurdly high number of times.

I expected that this function would just be called no more than once for each item in the dropdown (i.e. loop through the options until a match is found). However, it is actually called exponentially more. E.g. for a dropdown with 1000 items and the 500th item bound to the ngModel, the function is called 501,001 times. If there are 3000 items in the dropdown and the 1500th item is selected, the `_compareWith` function is called 1,002,501 times. It gets even worse if an option nearer the end of the list is selected.

## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-select-performance?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

Note that I added a custom `compareWith` method in this example to log how many times it is called, but the performance is just as bad with the default internal comparison method.

I think the problem stems from Angular's `SelectControlValueAccessor.writeValue()` method being called over and over for each individual option element that is rendered, rather than once after all the options are rendered.

## ğŸŒ  Your Environment

**Angular Version:** 11.2.6

**Anything else relevant?**
This is especially problematic for our users with slower mobile devices.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Select dropdowns with ngValue binding perform far worse than expected" (#41330)

Issues.Title: DEFAULT_CURRENCY_CODE is not the right way for default currency code
Issues.Body:
<!--ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…

Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…-->


# ğŸš€ feature request

### Relevant Package
 @angular/common

### Description
With current implementation, developers have to mannually specify the `DEFAULT_CURRENCY_CODE`, if they use a different locale rather than `en-us` and want to use the currency meta along with that locale.

here is how currency pipe implements:
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/c49b28013a6c017c9afc73bbc00bb4fdcf15c70e/packages/common/src/pipes/number_pipe.ts#L205-L208

In fact, there is a function to get currency code from a target locale
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/c49b28013a6c017c9afc73bbc00bb4fdcf15c70e/packages/common/src/i18n/locale_data_api.ts#L488

I believe using the currency code from specified locale is the right way to go, rather than specifying it mannually.

### Describe the solution you'd like
deprecate the use of `DEFAULT_CURRENCY_CODE`, in favor of `getLocaleCurrencyCode` in currency pipe.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
There are always the alternatives, but not the elegant way.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "DEFAULT_CURRENCY_CODE is not the right way for default currency code" (#41323)

Issues.Title: Perf in logs
Issues.Body: ## feat(language-service): add perf tracing to LanguageService Adds perf tracing for the public methods in LanguageService. If the log level is verbose or higher, trace performance results to the tsServer logger. This logger is implemented on the extension side in angular/vscode-ng-language-service. ## how to view perf tracing in vscode. 1. set angular log level to verbose 2. Run vscode action: "Open Angular Server Log" ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7720245/112059607-47348680-8b19-11eb-8530-7fa492e58f6b.png) 3. Search for lines matching `LanguageService#` ### grepping for log files while testing, I saved the patch to the angular server log to an environment variable and use grep to search for perf tracing. ``` # grep --text LanguageService# $NG_SERVER_LOG ``` ## Test plan This PR was tested manually against a local build of the vscode extension. I made sure that perf tracing showed up for each public method in `LanguageService` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7720245/112059855-a85c5a00-8b19-11eb-9188-a83b47d14bb5.png)

Issues.Title: Schematics Schema Organziation: $ref for local files ([ERR_INVALID_URL]: Invalid URL)
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ Feature request
I checked the issue trackers but it seems I'm dealing with something that wasn't asked for before and I still hope you consider that feature, as it's something you use inside your own code base too.

### Command (mark with an `x`)
This is about the devkit/schematics and the schema resolution. So I removed the list of commands, it's about the underlying schematics engine and the way it resolves json schema files.

### Description
We are working a lot with Angular Schematics. Authoring the schema.json files per schematic is straight-forward. In addition we also use `quicktype` to create typescript definitions for a safer handling of the involved data. To complete this setup we also try to split schematics in order to reuse or test them individually. This means some of the schematics are private. 

This approach of splitting schematics creates a lot of repetition in the actual schema.json files. It happens often that we repeat dozens of schema properties across multiple schematic as they are related and sharing the same schematic API surface.

A common solution to make this easier is to use $ref and combine different definitions with `allOf`. This is also exactly what you are doing in the command definitions:

See here:
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/81fcfb774f3a1f1ee83e1b4ba86ffcb323c8b331/packages/angular/cli/commands/build.json#L1-L16

And it seems this is only possible for the command runner as you register the required custom uri handler for local files only in there:

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/81fcfb774f3a1f1ee83e1b4ba86ffcb323c8b331/packages/angular/cli/models/command-runner.ts#L124-L133

The `ng-cli://` is the prefix for the [json schema `$id`](https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/structuring.html#the-id-property) (like `"$id": "ng-cli://commands/build.json"`) and allows to refer to definitions without repeating the source json file. I don't fully understand why it's working and I might miss some processing step on your side. What I see are `$ref` and `$id` references and I would like to use them too.

We users of common schematics can't do that as the usual workflow (node for us) is not receiving any capabilities to load local schema files.

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/81fcfb774f3a1f1ee83e1b4ba86ffcb323c8b331/packages/angular_devkit/schematics/src/workflow/base.ts#L69-L70

If I try to use a ref I see an error thrown by the registry as the file is not located in the web (http)

> An error occured:
> TypeError [ERR_INVALID_URL]: Invalid URL: my-definition.json
>    at onParseError (internal/url.js:259:9)
>    at new URL (internal/url.js:335:5)
>   at node_modules/@angular-devkit/core/src/json/schema/registry.js:88:25

### Describe the solution you'd like
Let me allow to use the full power of schemas to tame our huge schema files and let me a allow to split them into smaller chunks. I would like to organize my schematics like so:

```
"allOf": [
    {
      "$ref": "my-definition.json#/definitions/part-a"
    },
    {
      "$ref": "my-definition.json#/definitions/part-b"
    }
  ]
```

You could solve this by adding a default URI resolver for local files to the `CoreSchemaRegistry` to allow the usual schematics (`yarn schematics @my/lib:do-something`) to be based on better organized json schemas. Is there a complexity I'm missing or would this be feasible at least ?

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I consider the following alternatives:

1. Create our own `$ref` & `flattening` approach to feed normalized `schema.json` files into the schematics engine while we can author the individual files. This is basically preprocessing an independent set of valid but better organized json schema files into a format that Angular understands. Also extract the typescript definition files from that final schema file to consume in the code.

2. Author Typescript files and share them however I like. Then derive the schema file. Same as 1) but order reversed.

Thanks for considering my issue. Very much appreciated
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Schematics Schema Organziation: $ref for local files ([ERR_INVALID_URL]: Invalid URL)" (#20374)

Issues.Title: build: determine release version from package.json instead of git tag
Issues.Body:
Currently, the version of a release is determined by the git tag.
This PR changes the release script to determine the release version from the
`version` property in the root `package.json`.

With this change, the caretaker will have to update the version in both
`package.json` and `latest-versions.ts` **after** the release.

Release doc has also been updated.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: determine release version from package.json instead of git tag" (#20353)

Issues.Title: @angular-devkit/build-angular required packages are requiring a peer of webpack@^4.0.0 with webpack "5.27.2" installed
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc - [x] npm install webpack@latest ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: "@angular-builders/custom-webpack": "11.0.0" "webpack": "4.43.0" ### Description We are using "@angular-builders/custom-webpack": "11.0.0" in our devDependencies, and everything worked as expected with the usage of "webpack": **"4.43.0"**. After we updated our "webpack" dependency to version **"5.27.2"** we got some warnings related to "@angular-devkit/build-angular" required packages, these are the warnings: - @angular-devkit/build-webpack@0.1102.5 requires a peer of webpack@^4.6.0 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself. - @ngtools/webpack@11.2.5 requires a peer of webpack@^4.0.0 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself. - webpack-dev-middleware@3.7.2 requires a peer of webpack@^4.0.0 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself. Issues.Title: Relative url() paths in styles are resolved incorrectly for non-root directory
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I'm not sure. ### Description It looks like the assets resolution mechanism (with or without `resourcesOutputPath`) always expects that stylesheets are placed in the root folder. If you use elaborate stylesheets configuration with subfolders it brokes relative URLs in stylesheets. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction I have 2 stylesheets `styles.scss` and `styles2.scss`, configured next way in `angular.json` ``` "styles": [ "src/styles.scss", { "input": "src/styles2.scss", "bundleName": "themes/style2" }, ``` both files have the same rule (just for testing) ``` h1 { background: url('./styles/some/relative/background.jpg'); } ``` after build or serve I have the next output ``` /styles.css /themes/styles2.css ``` _but_ relative paths in both cases resolved as for a file located in the root, i.e. `background: url(background.png);` ### Expected behavior The relative path in `styles2` should be resolved as `../background.png` ## ğŸŒ Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 10.0.5
Node: 12.18.3
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.0.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

Issues.Title: Build error because of license-webpack-plugin with webpack 5, ModuleFederation plugin.
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, error happens after this [commit](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/ea02b6e94710d43ab9c2738765c17d234dce353e#diff-5b54a4601b5d50cc0617712190a902a19f4ea2d044c836e98d5cf8e9e6c4a6f3) ### Description New clean project with webpack 5 and ModuleFederation plugin: ng build fails if `extractLicenses` is `true`. A package `@angular-devkit/build-angular` (0.1102.5) has dependency `license-webpack-plugin` (2.3.11) which has an issue has been solved in this [commit](https://github.com/xz64/license-webpack-plugin/commit/a22b4a64f94de1edcde83f2c745ffa0201eee244#diff-5a5c513f0d9f5557331f013846e996727746302e89b394c0b705c1e7affd65b1). This fix is available from version 2.3.13 of `license-webpack-plugin`. Versions of `@angular-devkit/build-angular` 0.1200.x has `license-webpack-plugin` with 2.3.15 version which hasn't this issue. This version update could be brought to 0.1102.x. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction Minimal reproduction is available [here](https://github.com/ikalyakin/angular-mf-example). Important: install dependencies using `yarn` (because of `resolutions` section in `package.json`) Also you can follow this steps: - generate new project with `ng new angular-mf-example --skip-tests --package-manager=yarn` - define `"webpack": "^5.4.0"` in `resolutions` section of `package.json` - change `architect.build.builder` to `ngx-build-plus:browser` - define `architect.build.builder.options.extraWebpackConfig` as `webpack.config.js` - create `webpack.config.js` with this [content](https://github.com/ikalyakin/angular-mf-example/blob/main/webpack.config.js) - create `src/bootstrap.ts` with this [content](https://github.com/ikalyakin/angular-mf-example/blob/main/src/bootstrap.ts) - update `src/main.ts` with this [content](https://github.com/ikalyakin/angular-mf-example/blob/main/src/main.ts) - run `ng build --prod` - get error `ENOENT: no such file or directory` ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error 

An unhandled exception occurred: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '\package.json'
See "C:\Temp\ng-CN9MLQ\angular-errors.log" for further details.
error Command failed with exit code 127
## ğŸŒ Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 11.2.5
Node: 14.15.4
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.2.6
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): create add schema method in ast-utils
Issues.Body: The AST Utils include methods to add new values to each section of an NgModule's metadata including `declarations`, `imports`, `providers`, `exports`, `bootstrap` and `entryComponents`. However, there is no method for schemas. Schematics authors can easily use the `addSymbolToNgModuleMetadata` method to achieve this capability, but I propose to add this `addSchemaToModule` method as a minor quality of life improvement.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@schematics/angular): create add schema method in ast-utils" (#20352)

-   **router:** fragment can be null ([#​37336](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/37336)) ([b555160](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/b5551609fe02787641bdfdb0a6edfded413a3b52)), closes [#​23894](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/23894) [#​34197](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/34197)

##### Features

-   **router:** add migration for ActivatedRouteSnapshot.fragment ([#​41092](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/41092)) ([190fa07](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/190fa07b9a416defb581d2bf76d1deef7baefce6)), closes [#​37336](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/37336)

##### BREAKING CHANGES

-   **animations:** DOM elements are now correctly removed when the root view is removed.
    If you are using SSR and use the app's HTML for rendering, you will need
    to ensure that you save the HTML to a variable before destorying the
    app.
    It is also possible that tests could be accidentally relying on the old behavior by
    trying to find an element that was not removed in a previous test. If
    this is the case, the failing tests should be updated to ensure they
    have proper setup code which initializes elements they rely on.
-   **router:** Strict null checks will report on fragment potentially being null.
    Migration path: add null check.

Issues.Title: Better support `ng new` use cases
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ Feature request

/cc @mgechev

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [X] new
- [X] generate

### Description

We should rethink some of the DX around `ng new`, as it was originally intended to make new Angular applications, but has expanded somewhat, particularly with monorepos. There are three things in particular which are a bit awkward:

1. There is no way to create an Angular library (using the CLI) without using a monorepo structure. This may not be desired and makes library authorship a little more awkward.
1. To use a monorepo structure, users are supposed to use `ng new --create-application=false`, which is a pretty awkward syntax and doesn't make clear that this is intended for a monorepo/multi-app workspace.
1. Reevaluate the definition of "workspace". I can't speak for others, but I always interpreted a "workspace" as effectively a monorepository for Angular apps. Looking through [docs](https://angular.io/guide/file-structure), it seems that anything with an `angular.json` file is technically a "workspace", so `ng new` technically creates a workspace, even though it isn't a monorepo. I think this definition of "workspace" only really applies internally so we should think more critically about the language here.

Additional context: https://twitter.com/justinfagnani/status/1373336274384293889

### Describe the solution you'd like

I'm thinking we could add an extra flag to `ng new` to decide whether to make a standalone application (`ng new --type app`), a multi-app workspace (`ng new --type workspace`, equivalent to today's `ng new --create-application=false`), or a standalone library (`ng new --type library`). Note that `ng new --type app` and `ng new --type library` both *technically* create a "workspace" per the above definition. We might want to either tweak the definition of "workspace" to mean "a multi-app Angular repo" or use something like `ng new --type empty-workspace`.

This would be distinguished from `ng generate` because `ng new` makes a new repository while `ng generate` works within an existing repository. Arguably we should merge `ng new` and `ng generate` (maybe inferring from file path context whether a new repository is required).

Some of the broader questions we should discuss:

1. How should we position Angular "workspaces"? Are they for monorepositories or not?
2. How should `ng new` and `ng generate` work together or be merged?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Apparently you can use `ng-packagr` to generate a library without a workspace, but you're losing a lot of the benefits of the CLI by doing so: https://twitter.com/Splaktar/status/1373373386802479105
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Better support `ng new` use cases" (#20351)

Issues.Title: help(MatTooltip): MatTooltip Disappears When Using MatTooltipClass
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->
![demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/213904/112392449-7e33a500-8c9d-11eb-8540-b1f86d5708ad.gif)

#### What are you trying to do?

Apply style to matTooltip using matTooltipClass. This works fine when running from a site created `ng new` even after migrating to SSR. However, the tooltip disappears almost immediately when running from a project created using `dotnet new angular`.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I'm *guessing* that it has something to do with the app that the dotnet template generates but haven't been able to determine what it might be after walking through creating a project from scratch using both `ng new` and `dotnet new angular` and comparing the projects. I've upgraded Angular and Material to the latest versions to eliminate the possibility that the problem only exists in older versions.

I'm not quite sure how to debug the show() function of the _MatTooltipBase class.

#### Reproduction

You can see the code and the steps I used to create it [here](https://github.com/rmegal/dotnetcorengspa).
  
#### Environment

- Angular: Latest
- CDK/Material: Latest
- Browser(s): Edge
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "help(MatTooltip): MatTooltip Disappears When Using MatTooltipClass" (#22339)

Issues.Title: refactor(cdk/overlay): use index files for public Sass API instead of copying files out
Issues.Body:
Currently we copy out a few of the CDK .scss files to the root of the `cdk` package so that they're more convenient to consume. The problem with this is that it prevents us from importing other Sass files, because the import path will be wrong after the files are copied (see #22043).

These changes rename the files to `_index.scss` which will allow users to maintain the same import paths while allowing us to remove the file copying logic and not having to worry about import paths.

**Note:** the commit message mentions `overlay` due to the linting rules, but this also applies to `a11y` and `text-field`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(cdk/overlay): use index files for public Sass API instead of copying files out" (#22343)

Issues.Body:

  https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/google-maps/map-geocoder/README.md
It has "takes" twice:
  "The MapGeocoder.geocode method takes takes the .."

It might also be helpful to some devs to mention in this README that GeoCoder is defined as ;
```
  @Injectable({providedIn: 'root'})
```
and so automatically works as a singleton service (e.g. no need to explicitly list it as a provider in AppModule) and perhaps add a link to this page:
  https://angular.io/guide/singleton-services

(same applies to MapDirectionsService)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-dialog): Tab content jumps a little right after dialog opening.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

![jumping_dialog_reproduction](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32300784/112313492-92cd6880-8cb0-11eb-9d50-a30f2f254e22.gif)

Here are the two adjacent frames extracted from the gif above, there you can see that alignment of elements is slightly different (if you don't see - I recommend to use page ruler to make sure I don't lie).
![frame_1 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32300784/112443198-56077d00-8d55-11eb-86ad-02e41f941f3a.png)![frame_2 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32300784/112443201-56a01380-8d55-11eb-8daf-2c34bc6f0d1a.png)


Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: 
- https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hwqwcc?file=src/app/dialog-overview-example-dialog.scss

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the given link and open/close dialog at least a few times.
2. If cannot reproduce the bug - enable max cpu throttling in devtools.

Option 2:
1.  Open the angular material documentation: https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/overview
2. Open/close first dialog at least a few times.
3. If cannot reproduce the bug - enable max cpu throttling in devtools.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Dialog content shouldn't move after dialog opens with that beautiful 'grow' style animation.


#### Actual Behavior
The dialog content is jumping a little (depends on what content it has). I'm afraid that the issue https://github.com/angular/components/issues/13870 also might be related to this bug. So it's the dialog's fault that expansion panel is expanded and content is jumping.

#### Environment

- Browser(s): Chrome (Version 89.0.4389.90 (Official Build) (64-bit))
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 latest version
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-dialog): Tab content jumps a little right after dialog opening." (#22323)
